abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings gave mixed results,
            for while the outcome is unsatisfactory, and impacts of
            institutional development were only modest, its
            sustainability is likely, based on the strong utilization of
            all investments, valid for the Pensions Records Management
            investment, as well as for basic information technology
            investments. While it is arguable that the Bank could have
            restored project implementation, based on a satisfactory
            quality at entry, major impediments were caused by the lack
            of government support to the agreed restructured program.
            The primary lesson reinforces the notion that government
            commitment is essential for project success, irrespective of
            changes among government officials. Further lessons suggest
            that the introduction of a new, and private pensions system,
            requires organizational, legal, and institutional
            arrangements, to be completed prior to initiation. In
            addition, a comprehensive approach would address policy
            issues, particularly for improved health insurance systems,
            and resolve structural deficits in revenue collection,
            eliminate undermining "gratuity" payments, and
            financial protection, and move towards acquiring medical
            services, and supplies, strengthening private medical
            delivery services. The politicized Social Insurance
            management should be transformed into a new professional
            cadre of civil servants, committed to achieve a functioning,
            and independent organization.
